item.title: TCP Congestion Control: From Slow Start to BBR
item.description:
Every time you load a webpage, stream a video, or download a file, TCP congestion control algorithms work invisibly to maximize throughput while preventing network collapse. These algorithms represent decades of research into one of networking’s hardest problems: how do independent senders share a network fairly without overwhelming it? Let’s explore how TCP congestion control evolved from simple beginnings to sophisticated model-based approaches.

1. The Congestion Problem

Without congestion control, networks collapse under load.

item.title: Network Sockets and the TCP/IP Stack: How Data Travels Across Networks
item.description:
Every web request, database query, and API call travels through the network stack. The simple act of opening a connection hides layers of protocol machinery handling packet routing, reliable delivery, congestion control, and flow management. Understanding how sockets work and how data traverses the TCP/IP stack illuminates why networks behave as they do and how to build efficient networked applications.

1. The Network Stack Overview

Before diving into details, let’s see the complete picture.
